channel.title: Building A Computer
channel.description:
Hey Guys
I want to build a nice good computer that is good at handling games with no lag, and can run on maximum graphics.
I have about $1500 to spend.
Where should I be looking?

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“Tatemo, post:27, topic:542761”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=661636.msg4423134#msg4423134 date=1399402361]

Mate, get the i5 and an R290, sorted.

  • a non reference cooler. Tbh you could put the graphics card on hold for a little while and save up for the 290. You can mine with the 290 too to make your cash back.
    [/quote]

“Mine to make your cash back” - HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA, OH MY GOD, THAT’S THE FUNNIEST SHIT I’VE HEARD IN MY LIFE. YOU SIR ARE A COMEDIAN.[/quote]
Oooh, mining isn’t a profit anymore. Soz, I wasn’t aware that not being in the loop anymore in regards to mining was so funny.

Read full topic

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Skyro, post:22, topic:542761”]How is that gpu bad? I don’t understand…>?

Also, what screen would you suggest for around the same price. I don’t really know much about screens.[/quote]
It’s not bad it’s a perfectly brilliant GPU, just a little unbalanced vs. your CPU, judging by your budget though I assumed you wanted some more grunt, for that kind of price range you can be getting top of the range almost, make it future proof

Read full topic

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

On board sound is better than cheap sound cards. Sound cards aren’t very useful, feel free to look up reviews/thoughts on them. They were useful back in the day but since on board sound has improved so much the only real use is it can drive headphones that have a higher resistance (I think). I found an old sound card that cost me a pretty penny back in 2011 but I chucked it out as I didn’t see a point in using it (I have a wireless headset so the amp wouldn’t of helped), drivers were a nightmare at times!

Get a better power supply (cheaper psu’s tend to have worse ripple etc). I didn’t bother checking the monitor you picked but get AH-IPS if possible. Viewsonic, asus, acer, dell are good options (you get good deals on viewsonic monitors + they’re great I have a viewsonic monitor).

Read full topic

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Skyro, post:19, topic:542761”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=661636.msg4422722#msg4422722 date=1399231185]

  • Stock heatsinks on most high end intel CPU’s are fine, I ran my i7 3770k on stock heatsink for ages running everything from 24 hour render tests to Metro 2033 on ultra.
  • Do you really need a blu ray player? Just buy an external USB one and then you can use it for any machines you have… 2014 now, internal DVD drives are dying out.
  • All the extra fans you added in that build are unnecessary, the case you selected already provides these. If you wish to overclock and need a bit of extra air flow in the future then you can always add them on afterwards.

Everything else is fine, though if you remove the above you could always upgrade the GPU you selected, it’ll be a bottleneck in comparison to the CPU
[/quote]
What do you mean about the bottlenecking?

Also, would you guys be able to tell me a really good/comfortable mouse ($70 max) & a nice case ($100 max)?

http://pcpartpicker.com/p/3EdFF

That is what I’ve got currently, If someone could change anything to make it better please do.

Budget $1500 Flat.[/quote]
He meant that your CPU has good performance but GPU doesn’t keep up. By upgrading GPU you get rid of this bottleneck and you can pull the maximum out of your CPU and GPU.

I don’t see why you want to use 1500$ on this when you could use much less and still use max graphic settings on all games. Especially when the monitor you chose only supports 60Hz.(60 FPS is maximum you can see from it and going over that causes screen tearing).

If I were you I would downgrade CPU and buy a monitor with better refresh rate or IPS panel if you care about the quality(IPS provides amazing color accuracy) over smoothness.

Read full topic

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

  • Stock heatsinks on most high end intel CPU’s are fine, I ran my i7 3770k on stock heatsink for ages running everything from 24 hour render tests to Metro 2033 on ultra.
  • Do you really need a blu ray player? Just buy an external USB one and then you can use it for any machines you have… 2014 now, internal DVD drives are dying out.
  • All the extra fans you added in that build are unnecessary, the case you selected already provides these. If you wish to overclock and need a bit of extra air flow in the future then you can always add them on afterwards.

Everything else is fine, though if you remove the above you could always upgrade the GPU you selected, it’ll be a bottleneck in comparison to the CPU

Read full topic

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Jc22493:

Honestly, you don’t need to spend over a grand (unless you can really spare the cash). I spent $550 on mine and it has run everything I’ve tried on ultra with no problems. (BF3, Skyrim, etc.)

It depends entirely on what you deem acceptable performance and “everything”. BF3 and Skyrim are fairly old games now, too.

Read full topic

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[s]Pretend the noctua is the 15 revision and not the 14 and if you’re uber sure you want it to be $1500 no more remove the fans which should knock $40 of the price. + look out out for deals I’m sure you can it for less (has well refresh comes out on the 10th so change the i5 4670k to the i5 4690k (?)).

PCPartPicker part list: http://pcpartpicker.com/p/3DF0f
Price breakdown by merchant: http://pcpartpicker.com/p/3DF0f/by_merchant/
Benchmarks: http://pcpartpicker.com/p/3DF0f/benchmarks/

CPU: Intel Core i5-4670K 3.4GHz Quad-Core Processor ($229.99 @ NCIX US)
CPU Cooler: Noctua NH-D14 65.0 CFM CPU Cooler ($71.95 @ Amazon)
Motherboard: ASRock Fatal1ty Z87 Killer ATX LGA1150 Motherboard ($124.02 @ Newegg)
Memory: Corsair Vengeance 8GB (2 x 4GB) DDR3-1600 Memory ($77.25 @ Amazon)
Storage: Samsung 840 EVO 250GB 2.5" Solid State Disk ($139.99 @ Micro Center)
Storage: Western Digital Caviar Black 1TB 3.5" 7200RPM Internal Hard Drive ($75.94 @ Amazon)
Video Card: Asus GeForce GTX 780 3GB DirectCU II Video Card ($499.99 @ NCIX US)
Case: Fractal Design Define R4 (Black Pearl) ATX Mid Tower Case ($99.99 @ Micro Center)
Power Supply: Corsair RM 550W 80+ Gold Certified Fully-Modular ATX Power Supply ($99.98 @ OutletPC)
Operating System: Microsoft Windows 7 Home Premium SP1 (OEM) (64-bit) ($89.98 @ OutletPC)
Case Fan: Corsair Air Series AF140 Quiet Edition 67.8 CFM 140mm Fan ($17.99 @ Amazon)
Case Fan: Corsair Air Series AF140 Quiet Edition 67.8 CFM 140mm Fan ($17.99 @ Amazon)
Total: $1545.06
(Prices include shipping, taxes, and discounts when available.)
(Generated by PCPartPicker 2014-05-04 09:11 EDT-0400)[/s]

I read your comment after I posted this.

I doubt you need an i7, go for an i5. Considering your budget I’d go for a cheaper motherboard. I doubt you need 16Gb of RAM 8 is fine. a gtx 660 can’t utilize 3Gb of vRAM go for a gtx 760. Go for a seagate or WD HDD. You don’t need a sound card. You should use the voltage step down adapters that come with your fans so no fan controller is needed. In regards to the power supply - 450W is more than enough for your build, I have an RM 550 (550w) powering a rig with a gtx 580 (soon to be a 780 ^_^) with plenty of power to spare. I’m not sure but I don’t think my PSU fan has ever turned on, I highly recommend the Corsair RM PSUs.
I’d think about reworking your budget a bit so you can afford a better GPU though, a gtx 760 is good n all but I don’t think it can max out demanding games (don’t quote me on that). I think my 580 is similar in performance to a gtx 660 which is slightly worse than the 760 and it reaally can’t max out games.

Read full topic

item.title: Building A Computer
item.dc:creator: @Tatemo Tatemo
item.description:
@Tatemo wrote:

You can dump the fan controller and most of those fans (if you are worried about it staying cool water cool it, fans are pretty useless past a point), also, 16gb of ram is unnecessary, most games won’t use 4gb and none will use more than 8gb.

Read full topic
